Some other things.
There are a lot of materials in our environment, especially things - chemicals, that leach out of plastics - that we now know, become part of our food, and many of them have hormone effects.
They behave like female hormones, estrogens, or they - some of them block androgens, male hormones.
And all - both of those properties cause weight gain.
A lot of the medications that we're taking.
You know, everybody's now taking psychoactive medications, anti-depressants, other mood-stabilizing drugs.
The number of prescriptions for these is just extraordinary.
And almost every one of them, even medications used to treat diabetes and used to treat blood pressure - almost all of these lead to weight gain.
You know, these researchers say, we don't know.
We don't know whether these are playing a significant role.
But there's at least as good evidence for these things, as there are for the big two that we've previously been focused on.
And it's possible, maybe even probable, that all of these things come to play in a single person.
I think that that probably is true.
That we don't know.
And it may be that one is more important than another, but I think it really is true.
So those were just a few other factors, besides diet and exercise, that may be contributing to the epidemic of obesity in America, and you can find all 10 at our website, NPR.org.

Well, let me ask this, Vanzetta, if you'll tackle it first, the $64,000 question, the reconstruction question if you will, the idea that while there's no question we're better off as a whole today than 50 years ago, there is this question of community and what was instilled in all of us and given to our children perhaps from a moral and social issue and value standpoint that is clearly sorely lacking today.
When you look at the two and the growth, how much do you say, `Maybe, you know, I'd give a little tradeoff on one side or another'?
That is a $64,000 question.

I think the status quo that we now have, namely a void in civility and manners and what we collectively call home training, the void I think is due in part to the fact that there is this challenge that has disappeared.
The very interesting thing about in-your-face racism and segregation is that it gives you a target.
It gives you an impetus, an incentive to overcome.
And I'm not suggesting that you always have to dangle the rabbit before the greyhound to get him to run around the track, but I am saying that that's a visible, tangible incentive.
The fact is that so many young Americans, both white and African-American and others, simply don't believe that there is a challenge to overcome now.
There is this conviction of entitlement.
There's a conviction that they have arrived.
There's a conviction that there is no issue, there is no problem.
They see you.
They see Fredricka Whitfield.
They see Colin Powell and Condoleezza Rice and they believe all is well.
And it isn't that they have this inner belief that I think all three of us had that they can do that.
They just don't think that there is as much of an obstacle to their doing it.
I think that's one issue.
Yeah.
